document.docAuthor: Johanson, Kjell Arne, Mary, Nathalie Jeanne, Sjöberg, Tin & Malm, Tobias
document.masterDocTitle: Eighteen new species of Oecetis McLachlan 1877 (Trichoptera, Leptoceridae) from New Caledonia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Eighteen new species of Oecetis McLachlan 1877 (Trichoptera, Leptoceridae) from New Caledonia

heading.emphasis:
Key to New Caledonian
Oecetis
species, males

paragraph.keyLead: 1 Tergum X divided into bilobed main branch and posterior spine ( Figs 1 , 21 , 57 ); upper posterolateral process on each side of segment IX not exceeding tergum X posteriorly............................................................. 2

- Tergum X lacking posterior spine ( Figs. 73-74 ); upper posterolateral process of segment IX exceeding tergum X posteriorly ( Fig. 73 ) …….......................................................................
Oecetis flucta
sp. nov.
2 Tergum X with posterior spine longer than main branch ( Figs 21 , 41 , 46 )......................................... 3
- Tergum X with posterior spine as long as ( Figs 6 , 16 , 31 , 88 ) or shorter than ( Figs 1 , 11 , 26 , 36 , 83 ) main branch........ 10
3 Tergum X with posterior spine curved strongly ventrad (Figs 51, 57, 62).......................................... 4
- Tergum X with posterior spine almost straight ( Fig. 21 ) or curved slightly ventrad ( Figs 41 , 46 , 67 , 78 )................. 6

4 Superior appendages as long as main branch of tergum X ( Fig. 57 ); posterior spine very long and more slender than coxopodites in lateral view ( Fig. 57 )..............................................................
Oecetis gracilis
sp. nov.

- Superior appendages about half as long as main branch of tergum X (Figs 51, 62); posterior spine about as thick as or thicker than coxopodites in lateral view (Figs 51, 62)............................................................... 5

5 Coxopodites curving slightly ventrad in lateral view ( Fig. 62 ); posterior spine uniformly curving along its length in lateral view ( Fig. 62 )........................................................................ …..
Oecetis rostra
sp. nov.

- Coxopodites curving slightly dorsad in lateral view (Fig. 51); posterior spine curving strongly ventrad after mid-length in lateral view (Fig. 51).................................................................
Oecetis multidentata
sp. nov.

6 Coxopodites exceeding posterior spine of tergum X posteriorly in lateral view ( Fig. 21 )............
Oecetis millei
sp. nov.
- Coxopodites not exceeding posterior spine of tergum X posteriorly in lateral view ( Figs 41 , 46 , 67 , 78 )................. 7

7 Main branch of tergum X thicker than posterior spine in lateral view ( Fig. 46 ); coxopodites each with long branch directed dorsad ( Fig. 46 ).............................................................. …..
Oecetis dorsospina
sp. nov.

- Main branch of tergum X more slender than posterior spine in lateral view ( Figs 41 , 67 , 78 ); coxopodites directed posterad ( Fig. 41 , 67 , 78 )........................................................................................... 8

8 Coxopodites curving ventrad along their length ( Fig. 78 )........................
Oecetis nouvellecaledonensis
sp. nov.
- Coxopodites not curving ventrad along their length ( Figs 41 , 67 )................................................ 9
10 Tergum X with posterior spine as long as main branch ( Figs 6 , 16 , 31 , 88 )....................................... 11
- Tergum X with posterior spine shorter than main branch ( Figs 1 , 11 , 26 , 36 , 83 )................................... 14

11 Coxopodites each with long, posteriorly curving, spine-like dorsal process ( Fig. 88 )...............
Oecetis ovata
sp. nov.

12 Coxopodites in lateral view each with rectangular basal half separated from slender distal half ( Fig. 31 )..................................................................................................
Oecetis rostrata
sp. nov.
- Coxopodites in lateral view each with basal half not rectangular ( Figs 6 , 16 )..................................... 13

13 Coxopodites in ventral view with wide and long mesal plates only at base ( Fig. 18 ); in lateral view with narrow triangular upper posterolateral process of segment IX ( Fig. 16 ).........................................
Oecetis loyolaensi
sp. nov.

- Coxopodites in ventral view with wide and short mesal plates at mid-length ( Fig. 8 ); in lateral view with wide triangular upper posterolateral process of segment IX ( Fig. 6 )..............................................
Oecetis ovula
sp. nov.

14 . Superior appendages long, exceeding rest of genitalia posteriorly and each with bifurcated apex in lateral view ( Fig. 11 ).....................................................................................
Oecetis ramosa
sp. nov.
- Superior appendages shorter than tergum X and each with rounded apex in lateral view ( Figs 1 , 26 , 36 , 83 )............. 15

15 . Coxopodites each with ventral branch at base ( Figs 83, 85 )................................
Oecetis variabilis
sp. nov.
- Coxopodites without ventral branches at base ( Figs 1 , 26 , 36 )................................................. 16

- Coxopodites in lateral view each with basal third less than 4 times taller than distal third ( Figs 21 , 36 ); main branch of tergum X straight in lateral view ( Figs 26 , 36 ); phallus less than four times longer than narrowest part in lateral view ( Figs 29 , 39 ) 17
